repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Agricultural Rehabilitation and
            Sustainable Land Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agricultural
            Rehabilitation and Sustainable Land Management Project for
            Burundi were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; Global Environment Objectives (GEO) outcomes
            were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            risk to GEO outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            satisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: depth over
            breadth in training and capacity building. While the failure
            rate of project financed Sub-projects (SPs) is very low, a
            recurring explanation for failed or lower-than-expected
            returns for some SPs pertains to beneficiary capacity for
            adhering to good practices, particularly in livestock. While
            the project provided over 275,000 person days of training,
            many of these agro technical in nature, there was a need for
            sustained monitoring or mentoring that may have improved the
            efficiency of outcomes. Performance based contracts for
            better performance. The incentive to Local Implementing
            Agencies (LIAs), both public and private, needs to be
            performance based. Project lessons show that Sustainable
            Land Management (SLM) needs to be economically interesting
            to be sustainable: Where the economic incentives were lower
            in the project, there was greater deterioration of
            project-financed SLM infrastructure, and vice versa. One
            further lesson emerging from the ICR review of project
            Monitoring and Evaluation (M and E) design relates to
            support units in the Bank. In exploring the issue of
            Agriculture Rehabilitation and Sustainable Land Management
            Project (PRASAB's) weak M and E design, the ICR team
            concludes that a contributing factor to the poor original
            design was the delivery of the project at precisely the
            moment of transition from the project design summary to the
            modern results framework.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Agricultural Rehabilitation and
            Sustainable Land Management Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Agricultural
            Rehabilitation and Sustainable Land Management Project for
            Burundi is to contribute to the recipient's goal of
            restoring the productive capacity and livelihoods of its
            rural population through ecologically and economically
            sustainable investments. The reallocation and extension are
            necessary to allow the project to continue to use
            efficiently and effectively its resources to: (i) respond to
            the pressing needs of project beneficiaries; and (ii) fund
            recently approved sub-projects. The reallocation of
            resources will help rebalance adequately resources between
            the training and the sub-project categories. In fact,
            overestimated training resources could not be disbursed in
            the short time frame while underestimated sub-project
            resources are being quickly disbursed due to high demands
            from the populations. The project objective continues to be
            achievable; the performance of the borrower and the
            implementing agency is satisfactory and the borrower has
            prepared an action plan acceptable to the Bank to complete
            the project. There are no outstanding audit reports and all
            reports are satisfactory to the Bank.

9832673.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Agriculture Rehabilitation
            Sustanaible Land Management Supplement Project :
            resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the rehabilitation
            project to support the agricultural sector in Burundi
            (PRASAB) is to support organizations of producers to
            increase agricultural production and fight against poverty
            through higher incomes while preserving natural resources.
            This will be done by financing activities to increase
            production and strengthen the institutional and technical
            capacity of producer organizations, government departments,
            private sector operators and groups involved in rural
            development. The procedure for involuntary resettlement is
            not, in most cases, triggered because people are affected by
            physical movement. It is triggered because the project
            activity requires the acquisition of land, and people may be
            affected because they cultivate the land, own buildings, use
            resources to water and feed animals, or use their property
            in any manner for economic, spiritual or other purpose. Such
            use would no longer be possible during or / and after the
            implementation of the project This project will affect three
            categories or groups; 1) an individual who is affected when
            he suffers loss of property, land or property and / or
            access to natural resources and / or economic response to
            the activities under the project, and to whom compensation
            is due; 2) a household which suffers if one or more of its
            members is affected by the activities of sub-project, either
            by the loss of property, land or loss of access or affected
            in any other manner by the activities of project and 3)
            vulnerable households which may have special needs that are
            different from those of most households.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Agriculture Rehabilitation
            Sustanaible Land Management Supplement Project : indigenous
            peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Pilot Plan of
            Action for Development of Batwa is participation in the
            implementation of high-priorities activities to boost
            socio-economic development in order for Batwa to move out of
            their extreme poverty, taking into account their needs. This
            will be done by financing activities to increase production
            and strengthen the institutional and technical capacity of
            producer organizations, government departments, private
            sector operators and groups involved in rural development.
            This Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP) reviews the
            country's legal and regulatory legislation regarding
            indigenous populations, and its socioeconomic conditions,
            and, draws the guidelines / safeguards to protect indigenous
            populations in and around the project, who may potentially
            suffer adverse impacts as a result of the project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Agriculture Rehabilitation
            Sustainable Land Management Supplement : environmental report

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Agriculture
            Rehabilitation Sustainable Land Management Supplement
            Project is to boost the development of the rural areas. This
            development has declined as a result of the civil war which
            has lasted 10 years. The project has specific calculations
            that will result in (a) improving food security of small
            farmers through increased agricultural production and
            products farmed in a sustainable manner; (b) an increase in
            income in rural areas, and thus reducing the poverty level;
            and (c) reduction of land degradation in specific places and
            strengthening the management of natural resources. Negative
            impacts regarding the project include: loss of grazing
            areas, increase of diseases, noise during pumping,
            disturbance of aquatic habitat, risk of collapse of dikes,
            risks of contamination of water by the use of pharmaceutical
            products, and declining fish stock.
